question: A function <katex>$f(x)=\begin{cases}\frac{e^{1/x}-1}{e^{1/x}+1},&x\ne0\\ 0&,&x=0\end{cases}$</katex> is
choices: differentiable at <katex>$x=0$</katex> but not continuous at <katex>$x=0$</katex>
explanation: RHL at 0: Let <katex>$x = h$</katex>. Divide by <katex>$e^{1/h}$</katex>. <katex>$\lim_{h \to 0} \frac{1-e^{-1/h}}{1+e^{-1/h}} = \frac{1-0}{1+0} = 1$</katex>.
